verses.text: One who works with haste will become rich, but one who loves pleasure will grow poor.
verses.comment: Here Sirach warns that pursuing pleasure leads to poverty, while diligence brings prosperity. This echoes Proverbs and cautions against self-indulgence which diverts us from God's call to discipline and virtue.

verses.text: Wine and women lead the wise astray, and he who keeps company with prostitutes will lose all sense.
verses.comment: This verse warns against the dangers of intemperance and immoral living, which can destroy wisdom and judgment. The biblical tradition consistently calls God's people to purity and self-control.

verses.text: Rashness will lead to old age before your time, and a wasted life will be filled with regret.
verses.comment: A life of folly shortens one’s days, while those who fear the Lord are promised a lengthened life in wisdom.

verses.text: He who trusts too quickly is lacking in understanding, and he who sins offends his own soul.
verses.comment: Discretion and cautious judgment—especially in trusting others—are necessary virtues. This aligns with the repeated call in Wisdom Literature to seek the Spirit’s guidance in all relationships.

verses.text: He who rejoices in wickedness will be condemned, but one who resists temptation gains mercy.
verses.comment: Condoning sin brings judgment, but overcoming temptation leads to God’s mercy and favor. Christ Himself resisted temptation (Heb. 2:18), giving us an example to follow.

verses.text: Never repeat a harsh word, and you will not suffer loss.
verses.comment: Gossip and tale-bearing lead to strife and brokenness. God's people are called to charity and discretion in speech.

verses.text: Do not tell others what you have heard, and you will not be harmed.
verses.comment: Maintaining confidentiality keeps peace between brothers. This is an early witness to the call for charity and forbearance in community.

verses.text: Whether it is about a friend or a foe, do not speak of it; unless it is a sin for you to be silent, do not reveal it.
verses.comment: This verse advises prudence about when (or if) to speak. There are times when silence is not only prudent, but righteous.

verses.text: For someone has heard you and watched you, and when the time comes he will hate you.
verses.comment: Our words can return to harm us if spoken without caution. The wisdom tradition warns of consequences for speaking loosely.

verses.text: Have you heard a word? Let it die with you. Be assured, it will not make you burst.
verses.comment: It is better to control one’s tongue than to cause harm by sharing needlessly. Mastery over speech is an ancient spiritual discipline.

verses.text: A fool will suffer labor pains to speak out what he knows, like a woman in labor with a child.
verses.comment: The analogy shows a fool's compulsion to share secrets. The wise are marked by self-restraint, while the fool cannot keep his peace.

verses.text: Like an arrow lodged in the flesh of the thigh, so is a word inside a fool.
verses.comment: Ill-spoken words fester and bring harm to all. This passage reminds us of the power our words can carry.

verses.text: Question your friend if he has done you wrong, and if he is guilty, rebuke him so he may not do it again.
verses.comment: Direct confrontation with charity and justice heals relationships. Christ repeats this command for community life in the gospels.

verses.text: If someone has spoken unkindly of you, let it be between you and him alone, unless he repeats it.
verses.comment: Confronting offenses privately follows the biblical pattern for resolving disputes in love and seeking reconciliation first in private.

verses.text: If he has done it, that he may not do it to you again; but if he has not done it, do not say a word.
verses.comment: Restoration is the goal, not revenge. The wisdom here prepares for the larger Christian call to mercy and reconciliation.

verses.text: There is one who keeps silent and is thought to be wise, and another who is hateful and is considered rash.
verses.comment: Silence can be mistaken for wisdom, and speaking out impulsively can reveal folly. True wisdom is a combination of prudent silence and timely speech.

verses.text: Some people keep quiet, for they have nothing to say, while others keep silent and wait for the right moment.
verses.comment: Distinguishing between the prudent and the ignorant reveals spiritual maturity. True wisdom waits for God's timing.

verses.text: A wise person is patient, but a fool is quick to speak and is counted worthy of nothing.
verses.comment: Patience and listening are the marks of wisdom, which are echoed in James’ call to be 'slow to speak, slow to anger' (James 1:19).

verses.text: The knowledge of the wise will increase like the rising tide, and their counsel will endure like a river.
verses.comment: Wisdom is a living stream that grows and brings life. This points forward to Christ, who is the true Wisdom and Living Water for the people of God.

verses.text: Instruction in faith is like a fountain of life to those who believe, and it will preserve them from destruction.
verses.comment: True doctrine is a fountain of salvation, and faithfulness to the teaching received preserves from error and loss. Jesus calls Himself the source of Living Water (John 4:14).

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is all wisdom, and all wisdom is in keeping with the law.
verses.comment: Wisdom and obedience to God’s law are inseparable. This principle underlies Jesus’ teaching in the Sermon on the Mount concerning the fulfillment of the law.

verses.text: Knowing wickedness is not wisdom, and there is a subtle cleverness that leads to deception.
verses.comment: True wisdom avoids evil and does not glory in being shrewd in wrongdoing. This verse distinguishes between cunning evil and holy wisdom.

verses.text: There is one who acts justly out of humility, but there is another who keeps quiet only to deceive.
verses.comment: Actions can look alike but their motives matter. Authentic humility brings justice; false humility can mask evil intentions.

verses.text: A silent person may be thought wise, yet may be hiding pride and a cunning heart.
verses.comment: True virtue is not only about actions but the interior disposition of the heart. Only God knows what is hidden.

verses.text: There is one who is silent and is found wise, yet another is detested for his loquaciousness.
verses.comment: Speech should be measured. Both over-speaking and over-silence must be guided by virtue and love of truth.

verses.text: A person who is outwardly humble, but whose inward part is filled with deceit, throws dust on his own head.
verses.comment: God sees the heart. True repentance and humility come not from outward acts alone, but from a transformed interior disposition.

verses.text: He who covers up his mouth with laughter while plotting evil is known and hated in the end.
verses.comment: Hypocrisy cannot be hidden from God or ultimately from people. The gospels warn repeatedly about the sin of hypocrisy.

verses.text: There is one who stumbles in speaking, but not with the intention to harm; who then has not sinned with his tongue?
verses.comment: We all fail in speech, as James confirms. God calls us to honesty and humility in our failings, seeking forgiveness and growth in holiness.

verses.text: A person is tested by his conversation, and everyone’s character is revealed by his words.
verses.comment: Our words reveal our hearts. Jesus warns that every careless word will come into judgment, so spiritual discipline in speech is critical.

verses.text: A person's dress, the way he laughs, and the way he walks all proclaim what he is.
verses.comment: Outward behavior often manifests inner disposition, but as the Lord told Samuel, man looks at outward appearance, but God sees the heart. Virtue should transform both our hearts and our lives outwardly.
